text: Infection of epithelial cells with the MERS virus induce slow , but significant , IFN type I and II responses [ 36 ] . Macrophages release pro - inflammatory chemokines and cytokines such as IL - 1β , IL - 6 and IL - 8 upon MERS - CoV infection [ 37 ] . Similarly , MERS - CoV infection in blood monocyte - derived macrophages and dendritic cells leads to the release of chemokines and cytokines , for example , IL - 2 , IL - 3 , CCL - 2 , CCL - 3 and RANTES [ 37 , 48 ] . Infection of activated T cells induces apoptosis via different pathways which may also explain the occurrence of lymphopenia [ 52 ] . With the present available knowledge , it is difficult to describe the exact pathogenesis of MERS - CoV , but it seems that viral replication in the macrophages results in extreme cytotoxicity and triggers the induction of pro - inflammatory chemicals which may lead to MERS - associated complications .
